learning_outcomes.description: Explain the legislation and relevant case law related to corporations and partnerships;
Apply the relevant legislation and/or case law to issues concerning corporations and partnerships;
Formulate advice on various legal issues associated with corporations and partnerships with reference to legislation and cases; and
Reflect critically on the legislation and relevant case law relating to corporations and partnerships.

assessments.task_description:
There will be 10 assessable tutorials this semester, as well as non-assessable tutorials for introducing IL&AC technique and discussing the Final Exam. The 10 assessable tutorials require students to submit a hand-written IL&AC answer to IL&AC questions which are released in tutorials during semester (see Learning Activities). Each of the ten (10) Assessable Tutorial Submission (ATS) questions are IL&AC problem questions using the IL&AC technique and are each worth a maximum of two (2) marks, each then totalling 20% of the overall course mark).

To receive full marks for a tutorial, students answers must make a serious and reasonable attempt at answering the ATS IL&AC question(s). A 'serious and reasonable attempt' is not necessarily a correct answer. However, the answer must demonstrate a genuine effort to engage with the question(s) using materials from lectures, the assigned texts, cases and statutes and other sources referenced either in lectures, the course Blackboard site or assigned texts.

Please take note of the following:

  • The question for each ATS will be released in the relevant tutorial. Students will be given time to read the ATS question, hand-write their own IL&AC answer to the question and answers will be briefly discussed at the end of each tutorial. Tutorials are not recorded and whilst brief guidelines about the answer to each question will be released, these guidelines will not be a full and formative answer to a submission - students must attend the scheduled tutorials during the semester to obtain the full benefit of the assessment and the discussion since this will aid them in their understanding of both the subject material and IL&AC answer technique;
  • At the end of the semester, a total mark out of 20 will be given to each student if, in the overall judgement of the course coordinator, the grading criteria set out in the CP have been satisfied.
  • Student answers to these submissions must be hand-written and submitted during each relevant tutorial.
  • This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To receive marks for an assessable tutorial students must:

1) Attend the tutorial for which they are enrolled, unless instructed otherwise; and

2) Submit their handwritten IL&AC answer in each relevant tutorial.

It is also important that students ensure that their names, student numbers and tutorial groups (eg T4) are clearly identified on their ATS submission. If these details are missing, answer may not be identified and marks allocated.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Hand written answers must be submitted during each relevant tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: 30% In-Semester IL&AC and Multiple Choice Question Exam
assessments.task_description:
This 30% IL&AC and Multiple Choice Question In-Semester Exam will be an on-campus invigilated exam. Any written or printed material is permitted in the exam; it may also be annotated. This includes dictionaries, texts, notes, and annotations. Electronic equipment is not permitted.

This 30% In-Semester Exam will occur in Teaching Week 8 outside of class time at a time and venue to be announced. Students will have 10 minutes reading time and 1 hour work-time to complete it.

The 30% In-Semester Exam will consist of two (2) IL&AC questions worth ten (10) marks each which will require answers using the IL&AC technique and multiple choice questions worth one (1) mark each.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This 50% Final Exam will be an on-campus hand-written invigilated exam. Any written or printed material is permitted in the exam; it may also be annotated. This includes dictionaries, texts, notes, and annotations.

This 50% Final Exam will occur during the UQ End-of-semester Exam Period and students will have 2 working hours and 10 minutes planning time to complete it.

The 50% Final Exam will consist of IL&AC questions problem based questions using the IL&AC technique. This assessment requires students to demonstrate their knowledge and understanding of relevant law through their written communication and analyse and apply critical thinking skills to produce an IL&AC answer. Students must carefully analyse and solve IL&AC problem questions, clearly justifying their answers, a skill that can be transferred to many areas in future careers. Further grading information will be made available on the course Blackboard website and further details about the final exam will be provided in lectures, workshops and on Blackboard during the semester.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 1 Lecture - Introduction to the Course and the Concept of Companies

This lecture will involve an introduction to the Course and discuss course structure (Lectures and Tutorials), Course Topics, the Assessment, Answering questions using the IL&AC (Issue, Law and Application, Conclusion) Technique, approaches on how to do well in this course and an outline of companies as a business entity.

Please Note: There are no tutorials in Teaching Week 1- Tutorials in this course commence from Teaching Week 2


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Teaching Week 1 Lecture - Introduction to the Course and the Concept of Companies
learning_activities.topic_description: Teaching Week 1 Lecture - Introduction to the Course and the Concept of Companies This lecture will involve an introduction to the Course and discuss course structure (Lectures and Tutorials), Course Topics, the Assessment, Answering questions using the IL&AC (Issue, Law and Application, Conclusion) Technique, approaches on how to do well in this course and an outline of companies as a business entity. Please Note: There are no tutorials in Teaching Week 1- Tutorials in this course commence from Teaching Week 2

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 2 Lecture - Characteristics and the Corporate Structure

In this lecture we will discuss the key characteristics of a company (separate legal personality, corporate capacity and limited liability) and their significance for company law, as well as different types of companies.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Teaching Week 2 Lecture - Characteristics and the Corporate Structure
learning_activities.topic_description: Teaching Week 2 Lecture - Characteristics and the Corporate Structure In this lecture we will discuss the key characteristics of a company (separate legal personality, corporate capacity and limited liability) and their significance for company law, as well as  different types of companies.

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 2 - Non-Assessable Tutorial

There will be assessable tutorials occurring during certain weeks during the semester which all students must attend. As an introduction to IL&AC technique, this tutorial in Teaching Week 2 will be non-assessable and will provide a non-assessable IL&AC question which students must handwrite an IL&AC answer to in the tutorial to help familiarise themselves with IL&AC questions and IL&AC technique.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Teaching Week 2 - Non-Assessable Tutorial There will be assessable tutorials occurring during certain weeks during the semester which all students must attend. As an introduction to IL&AC technique, this tutorial in Teaching Week 2 will be non-assessable and will provide a non-assessable IL&AC question which students must handwrite an IL&AC answer to in the tutorial to help familiarise themselves with IL&AC questions and IL&AC technique.

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 3 Lecture - Constituting and Managing Companies

In this lecture we will discuss the concept of corporate governance, company internal governance rules and describes their legal effect, sources, enforcement and modification and the division of powers in a company, including the effect of that division on members' and directors' roles

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 4 Lecture - Corporate Finance - Equity and Debt

In this lecture we discuss the basic concepts of corporate finance, including equity (share) and debt (loan) capital; how to become and cease to be shareholder, subscription and transfers on the secondary share market, and the duty to provide disclosure with public offers; the share capital maintenance rule, share capital transaction provisions and rules on dividends.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Teaching Week 4 Lecture - Corporate Finance - Equity and Debt

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 5 Lecture - Members Powers

In this lecture we discuss members' powers; the type of members' meetings and the rules about calling, holding and attending members' meetings, as well valid decision-making by members.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 6 Lecture - Directors, Officers and Members - Decisions, Restrictions and Corporate Contracting

In this lecture we discuss the role of directors, secretaries and other officers in a company; How directors and members make and delegate valid decisions, accessing company information; restrictions on member decision-making and the world of corporate contracting.

Please note: next week is the UQ In-Semester Break - No UQ classes- classes resume in Teaching Week 7.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 7 - Directors and Officers Duties 1

In this lecture we begin our discussions of directors' and officers duties; including the duties of care and diligence, the duties to act in good faith in the best interests of the company; the duty to avoid insolvent trading, the duty to avoid creditor defeating dispositions and the duty to avoid conflicts of interest.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 11 Lecture - Disclosure - Records, Reporting and Auditors

In this lecture we discuss various disclosure duties, including the duty to keep financial records, reporting requirements and the roles and duties of auditors.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 12 Lecture - Privacy and Data Protection

In this lecture we discuss laws on data protection and privacy and how they relate to companies, including regulations on collecting, generating, storing, accessing, using or sharing data and information.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Week 13 Lecture - External Administration and Winding Up

In this lecture we discuss external administration and how companies ar ewound-up, including the processes by which persons other than the directors assume management functions for a company, particularly the statutory processes for managing insolvent companies through winding-up and voluntary administration.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
